channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nature Retracts Study Predicting Catastrophic Climate Toll
item.description: While growing evidence shows that carbon emissions are harming the economy, the journal Nature found that an outlier paper had deep flaws.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Zillow Removes Climate Risk Scores From Home Listings
item.description: The scores aimed to predict a property’s risk from fires, floods and storms, but some in the real estate industry as well as homeowners have called them inaccurate.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown

item.title: U.S. Black Friday Sales Defy Tariffs and Economic Woes
item.description: Data on spending this week shows that consumers are shopping big for the holidays despite inflation and economic worries.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: U.K. Budget Plan Calms Markets and Labour Faithful. Will It Appeal to Voters?
item.description: The plan presented by the chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, called for spending increases and higher taxes on the wealthy and the middle class.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Market Volatility Underscores Epic Buildup of Global Risk
item.description: Some experts see a dangerous combination of factors reminiscent of practices that led to previous financial crises.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Trump Administration Is Taking Billions in Stakes in Firms Like Intel
item.description: The Trump administration is spending billions of dollars on deals with ownership stakes in companies. The unusual practice shows no sign of slowing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Xi Presses Trump on Taiwan as They Agree to Meet in China in April
item.description: In an unusual move, Xi Jinping, the leader of China, called President Trump. The two spoke about trade, Taiwan and Ukraine, according to separate official statements.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Edward Wong

item.title: Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine Prompts Debate Over Europe’s Military
item.description: With Russia looming, governments race to rebuild armed forces that shrank after the Cold War, grappling with hard issues of economics, politics and military strategy.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: What the Jobs Report Tells Us About the Economy
item.description: What does the September jobs report, delayed by six weeks because of the government shutdown, say about the economy? Lydia DePillis, our economics reporter, describes how the report, which was better than expected, comes at a moment of deep uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis, Claire Hogan, Stephanie Swart, Gabriel Blanco and Jacqueline Gu

item.title: A Tap-to-Pay Society Is Leaving These New Yorkers Behind
item.description: As fewer people carry cash, vendors, street performers and people experiencing homelessness and unemployment are at a disadvantage.
item.dc:creator: Anna Kodé and Daniel Arnold

item.title: Job Gains Disguise Weakness Beyond Service Industries
item.description: The unemployment rate rose in September as more people looked for jobs, according to data delayed by the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: September Jobs Report Injects More Uncertainty Into Fed’s December Decision
item.description: Policymakers at the central bank are at odds over the need to cut interest rates for a third straight meeting, as inflation picks up again and the labor market slows down.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Delayed Jobs Data to Give Snapshot of a Labor Market Under Stress
item.description: Economists expect that employment growth was anemic in September, before the government shutdown delayed data collection.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: This report will be the last one until mid-December.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Colby Smith

item.title: California Has a Legal Clause for Housing That Could Put NIMBYs in a Corner
item.description: For years, the state has been nudging its cities to build housing to address a severe shortage. Maybe what they needed was a shove.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty and Gabriela Bhaskar

item.title: After Shutdown, Labor Department Says Some Data is Gone for Good
item.description: Surveys were delayed and some cannot be collected at all, officials said, further complicating the Federal Reserve’s decision on interest rates next month.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Colby Smith

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Sent Trade Plummeting in August
item.description: The steep tariffs President Trump issued in August led to a contraction in imports and the trade deficit, newly released data shows.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: A City Is Broke. Can Billionaires’ Urbanist Dream Offer It a Last Chance?
item.description: Suisun City has tried to revive its fortunes for years. The latest idea: Annex land owned by California Forever, a tech-billionaire-funded plan for a new city north of San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty

item.title: Trump Says America Is in ‘Golden Age,’ Straining to Address Affordability
item.description: Speaking at a gathering of McDonald’s franchise owners and operators, the president boasted that he had “normalized” inflation.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green

item.title: High Beef Prices? Trump Official Blames Biden and Migrants.
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said migrants were bringing sick cows across the border, snarling beef supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
